Dear Mr. Ziomkowski:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
January 27, 2021. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations, why the prior CAP failed to achieve compliance.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4166 Discharge plan.
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care, all of
the following information shall be documented in the case
record within 14 days after discharge:
(b) A brief summary or other documentation of the services
provided while in residence, including medical and dental
services.
(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs that remain to be
met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the facility after
discharge.
(e) A statement that the discharge plan recommendations,
including medical and dental follow up that is needed,
have been reviewed with the resident and with the parent
and with the responsible case manager.
(f) The name and official title of the person to whom the
resident was discharged.
Two of two closed youth files reviewed lacked documentation of the items required
in subsection (b) through (f).
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
The facility serves a refugee population that is not under the ISEP monitoring
regulations.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract/Policy violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included
in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
The facility does not have a contract with DHHS that is regulated by DCWL. They
have a contract regulated through the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR).
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Reviewed rule 400.4166 discharge planning, action summaries, and Bethany
transfer/closing summary forms. Discussed needed additions to be in
compliance with the rules.
4

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not in need of consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The facility has submitted no acceptable corrective action plans required not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
During the unannounced onsite inspection, I completed a tour of the facility. The
facility was well maintained and clean. The youth bedrooms were full of appropriate
items, bathrooms were clean, medications were locked, and meal menus were
posted. Ample food was observed in the house. Random bedroom checks were
completed in varying intervals not to exceed 15 minutes when youth were asleep or
otherwise outside staff line of sight. I completed interviews with staff, who reported
feeling supported by management and enjoyment in their employment. Staff are
trained in physical management, CPI but have never had to participate in one during
the period under review. I interviewed three youth during the onsite visit. The youth
interviewed reported feeling safe at Bellaview and stated staff are respectful to them.
They liked the program and reported a variety of independent living skill development
opportunities. All youth were enrolled in school. There were no concerns noted by the
youth or staff.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the facility will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
